messages.content: what is the current situation of US Dollars money supply ?

The money supply in the U.S. has been steadily increasing over time. Here are some key facts about the current situation of U.S. dollars money supply:

• M1 money supply, which includes physical cash and checkable deposits, was around $4.5 trillion as of June 2021. This represents an increase of over 50% from pre-pandemic levels in early 2020.

• M2 money supply, which includes a broader measure of money including savings accounts, money market funds, and other time deposits, was around $20 trillion as of June 2021. This is up about 30% from early 2020.

• The Federal Reserve has taken aggressive actions in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, including cutting interest rates to near zero and expanding its balance sheet through bond purchases. These actions have helped increase the money supply.

• The large increase in money supply has fueled concerns about rising inflation. Some critics argue that the money supply growth has been excessive and unsustainable. However, the Fed maintains that the increase is a temporary response needed to support the economy during the pandemic.

• For reference, M2 money supply was around $11.5 trillion in early 2008 at the start of the Great Recession. The current level of over $20 trillion represents significant money supply growth over the last decade.

So in summary, the money supply in the U.S., as measured by various definitions, has expanded substantially in recent years and especially since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. The long-term implications of this large increase remain unclear and debated among economists.
What is the money supply situation since the end of covid pandemic

The money supply situation has remained elevated even after the end of the initial phases of the COVID pandemic:

• The Federal Reserve has continued its bond purchase program and kept interest rates at near zero levels to support the economic recovery. This has continued to put upward pressure on the money supply.

• As of June 2022, M1 money supply stood at $4.7 trillion, up about 4% from a year ago. M2 money supply was at $21.6 trillion, up 8.5% from a year ago.

• While economic growth has picked up, it has not been fast enough to absorb all of the money supply increase. This continues to fuel concerns about rising inflation pressures.

• Inflation has remained significantly above the Fed's 2% target. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose 9.1% in June 2022 from a year ago, representing the fastest pace of inflation since 1981.

• Some economists argue that the elevated money supply, along with supply chain issues and other factors, are contributing to higher inflation. Others believe that the money supply increase is not a major driver of current inflation pressures.

• The Federal Reserve has begun raising interest rates aggressively and has signaled more rate hikes are coming in an attempt to bring inflation under control. However, the Fed's actions so far have not yet resulted in a decline in the money supply.

So in summary, while the initial surge in the money supply was a response to the COVID crisis, the money supply has remained elevated even after the end of lockdowns and other pandemic restrictions. The Fed is now taking steps to tighten monetary policy and reign in inflation, but this has yet to translate into a reduction in the broader money supply figures.
Are we in Quantitative Easing or Quantitative Tightening policy ?

Currently, the Federal Reserve is in the process of transitioning from a policy of quantitative easing to one of quantitative tightening. Here are the details:

• For most of the pandemic, the Fed pursued an aggressive policy of quantitative easing in order to stimulate the economy. This involved large-scale purchases of assets, mainly Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities. These purchases injected massive amounts of liquidity into the financial system and contributed to higher money supply growth.

• The goal of quantitative easing was to reduce long-term interest rates, provide stimulus to the economy, and support asset prices. It was seen as a necessary response to deal with the economic fallout from the pandemic.

• However, with inflation now running much higher than expected, the Fed has begun the process of quantitative tightening. This involves allowing the assets on the Fed's balance sheet to roll off as they mature, without reinvesting the proceeds.

• This process effectively removes money from the financial system and puts downward pressure on the money supply. The goal is to combat inflation by reducing excess liquidity and tightening financial conditions.

• The Fed started quantitative tightening in June 2022 by allowing $47.5 billion of assets to roll off its balance sheet each month. It plans to ramp this up to $95 billion per month later in 2022.

• In addition to quantitative tightening, the Fed has also been raising interest rates aggressively to fight inflation. Higher rates also work to tighten financial conditions and slow money supply growth.

So in summary, while the Fed pursued quantitative easing policies during the height of the pandemic, it is now transitioning to quantitative tightening in order to bring inflation under control. This involves both raising interest rates and allowing its asset holdings to roll off, removing liquidity from the system.
